title: USS Moberly (PF-63)
text:
USS "Moberly" (PF-63), a , was the only ship of the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> to be named for <a href="Moberly%2C%20Missouri">Moberly, Missouri</a>.
Construction.
"Moberly" (PF-63), originally designated as PG-171, was reclassified PF-63 on 15 April 1943, laid down as "Scranton" under <a href="Maritime%20Commission">Maritime Commission</a> contract by <a href="Globe%20Shipbuilding%20Company">Globe Shipbuilding Company</a> in <a href="Superior%2C%20Wisconsin">Superior, Wisconsin</a>, on 3 November 1943, launched on 26 January 1944, sponsored by Mrs Howard J Snowden. She was renamed "Moberly" on 28 June 1944, placed "in service" from 1 to 7 September, during transfer to <a href="Houston">Houston</a>, Texas, for completion of construction by <a href="Brown%20Shipbuilding">Brown Shipbuilding</a>, and commissioned at Houston on 11 December 1944.
Service history.
After <a href="Shakedown%20%28testing%29">shakedown</a> off <a href="Bermuda">Bermuda</a>, "Moberly" reported to the <a href="United%20States%20Atlantic%20Fleet">Atlantic Fleet</a> on 8 February 1945 for escort duty. Assigned to <a href="Task%20Group">Task Group</a> 60.01 (TG 60.1), she departed <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>, 22 February in the screen of <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a>n bound <a href="convoy">convoy</a> UGS-76. She reached <a href="Oran%2C%20Algeria">Oran, Algeria</a>, 10 March, then sailed on the 18th with westbound convoy GUS-76. Transferred to TG-60.7 on 29 March, she joined the eastbound convoy UGS-82 in the mid-<a href="Atlantic">Atlantic</a> and returned to Oran on 8 April. Once again, the frigate sailed for the United States on 17 April. The escorts left the convoy off New York about noon on 5 May and headed for <a href="Boston%2C%20Massachusetts">Boston, Massachusetts</a>.
In company with and , "Moberly" approached <a href="Buzzards%20Bay">Buzzards Bay</a> late that afternoon, only two days before Germany surrendered. At 18:54, on orders from CTG 60.7 in , then at the southern entrance to the <a href="Cape%20Cod%20Canal">Cape Cod Canal</a>, the ships turned about to search for a German <a href="submarine">submarine</a> off <a href="Block%20Island">Block Island</a>. At 1740, had <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed and sunk "Black Point" a <a href="Collier%20%28ship%20type%29">collier</a> within sight of <a href="Point%20Judith%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Point Judith, Rhode Island</a> as she headed to <a href="Boston%2C%20Massachusetts">Boston</a>.
The group reached the area at 19:20 and after forming a scout line off Block Island, they began a sweep seaward at 20:10. Within 15 minutes, "Atherton" detected a submarine <a href="Submarine%20snorkel">snorkel</a> and the <a href="destroyer%20escort">destroyer escort</a> dropped magnetic <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a>s at 20:28, and during the next 30 minutes fired two <a href="Hedgehog%20%28weapon%29">Hedgehog</a> pattens.
Working as a <a href="hunter-killer%20group">hunter-killer group</a>, "Atherton" and "Moberly" continued the search and destroy operation. At 23:41 the escort launched another Hedgehog attack which brought large amounts of oil, air bubbles, and <a href="debris">debris</a> to the surface. The two ships delivered four more attacks in the early hours of 6 May and by dawn, oil and <a href="flotsam">flotsam</a> covered the area. The ships noted evidence of <a href="Plank%20%28wood%29">planking</a>, <a href="life%20raft">life raft</a>s, a <a href="chart">chart</a> <a href="sand%20table">tabletop</a>, <a href="clothing">clothing</a> and an officer's <a href="cap">cap</a>, which indicated success in the earlier attacks. To be certain, they continued the assault throughout the morning, then at 1240, TG 60.7 headed for Boston with "<a href="Clean%20sweep%20%28naval%29">brooms at mastheads</a>."
"Moberly" operated between Boston and New York until 31 July when she sailed with three other frigates for the <a href="Pacific">Pacific</a>. She transited the <a href="Panama%20Canal">Panama Canal</a> on 8 August and reached <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> on the 23rd. Six days later "Moberly" and sailed for the <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshall Islands</a> to begin weather station and plane guard patrols. The frigates reached Majuro on 5 September, and during the next six months they alternated on patrolling their assigned area out of Majuro and later out of <a href="Kwajalein">Kwajalein</a>.
"Moberly" returned to the west coast early in April 1946 and subsequently served in the <a href="13th%20Naval%20District">13th Naval District</a>. She decommissioned on 12 August 1946. Authorized by the <a href="Secretary%20of%20the%20Navy">Secretary of the Navy</a> for disposal on 29 August, "Moberly" was struck from the <a href="Navy%20list">Navy list</a> on 23 April 1947. She was sold for scrapping to <a href="Franklin%20Shipwrecking%20Company">Franklin Shipwrecking Company</a> of <a href="Hillside%2C%20New%20Jersey">Hillside, New Jersey</a>, on 27 October 1947.
"Moberly" received one <a href="battle%20star">battle star</a> for <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> service.
